title: Retired Eagles DE Chris Long calls officiating 'a mess,' says NFL needs to do something
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: USA TODAY Sports' Lorenzo Reyes sat down with former NFL defensive end Chris Long to discuss the current state of social activism in professional sports. USA TODAY

NEW YORK – Chris Long was like many of you, NFL fans -- confused by what he was watching.

Long, the former defensive end who retired in May, was watching Monday night’s Green Bay Packers-Detroit Lions game when an illegal hands to the face penalty was mistakenly called on Lions defensive end Trey Flowers on third down late in the game. The penalty extended Green Bay’s drive, and Detroit had used all its timeouts, so the Packers drained the clock and kicked the game-winning field goal for a 23-22 victory.

“Yeah, I was sitting there just as dumbfounded as everybody else Monday night when those two penalties cost Detroit the game,” Long told USA TODAY Sports on Wednesday.

On Tuesday, NFL executive vice president of football operations Troy Vincent said “when you look at it and you review the play, it’s not something that you want to see called in that particular pass rush” and that “the foul wasn’t there.”

Long isn't alone in his criticism of the officiating. Several players and coaches have complained this season, citing inconsistency on enforcement. In the spring annual meetings, NFL ownership approved a measure to grant coaches the ability to challenge pass-interference calls, and non-calls to be reviewed and potentially overturned when there is “clear and obvious” evidence to support an overturn.

On Wednesday, NFL commissioner Roger Goodell said the interference challenge rule is “what we anticipated.” In practice, however, only one challenge has been overturned so far this season.

“I don't think that officiating is going to ruin the game, but it's something that they need to rectify, because one thing the NFL doesn't like is all this noise that's un-ignorable from social media and the media and [the NFL] will be reactive,” Long said. “They were reactive to the holding calls spiking way up the first month of the season. They need to be reactive to some of these issues, too.

Chris Long says the NFL needs to do something about officiating issues. (Photo: Bill Streicher, USA TODAY Sports)

“The (defensive pass interference) thing, less than 10 percent are getting overturned, so coaches aren't throwing flags in situations where it should be clearly a DPI. It's a mess right now, but it's not going to ruin the game because people aren't going to turn it off.”

Browns quarterback Baker Mayfield called officiating “pretty bad” in Sunday’s 32-28 Cleveland loss against the Seattle Seahawks. New Orleans Saints defensive end Cam Jordan, after officials blew dead a scoop-and-score fumble in Week 2 and negated the touchdown, blasted the “Foot Locker” crew of officials.

Long understands it but believes even with the criticism, fans will tune in, calling football “addictive.”

Still, after an infamous missed defensive pass interference in last year’s NFC Championship game almost certainly cost the Saints a trip to the Super Bowl, and after the missed call Monday night cost the Lions a chance to win, there’s a legitimate claim that the NFL product is suffering with officiating mistakes.

“The Lions are a good football team,” Long said. “That's the worst part about it. This could impact their playoff opportunities.”

OH MY GOD THE REFS LOST THE LIONS A GAME!!! — Chris Long (@JOEL9ONE) October 15, 2019

Long spoke to USA TODAY Sports on behalf of Crown Royal, as part of its Water Break campaign that advocates for responsible alcohol consumption by taking a water break to stay hydrated.

Long, playing devil’s advocate, said adding another official in the booth to review all missed calls would lead to a cleaner game, but acknowledged that it would greatly slow the pace of play.

“I think that the NFL has got a moving target to hit and they got to hit it fast,” he said. “… They've got to get more consistent.”
description: Ex-Eagles DE Chris Long is retired from the NFL but still consumes the game. He criticized officiating for being inconsistent and a "mess."
